Pre-Lecture 12 Reading Before the lecture you should read: 8.2.2 Confidence Interval for the Population Mean When Sampling from a Normal Distribution with Unknown Population Variance In LAB 8.2.3-8.2.6 8.2.7 Confidence Interval for the Mean Difference When the Differences Have a Normal Distribution

Example 8-8 Use R, either via RStudio on your own device or this online console. # These functions and data may be useful library(PASWR2) HOUSE$price qqnorm() qqline() # First approach mean() sd() qt() # Second approach t.test() Solution library(PASWR2) qqnorm(HOUSE$price) qqline(HOUSE$price) xbar <- mean(HOUSE$price) CT <- qt(0.975, 13) # critical t value ST <- sd(HOUSE$price) # standard deviation xbar + c(-1, 1) * CT * ST/sqrt(14) [1] 198.5424 272.3433 # Second approach t.test(HOUSE$price, conf.level = 0.95)$conf [1] 198.5424 272.3433 attr(,"conf.level") [1] 0.95 # For full solutions see textbook/lecture slides

Example 8-17 Use R, either via RStudio on your own device or this online console. # These functions and data may be useful library(PASWR2) SUNDIG$difference qqnorm() qqline() # First approach mean() sd() qt() # Second approach t.test() # Third approach t.test(,,paired=TRUE) Solution library(PASWR2) qqnorm(SUNDIG$difference) qqline(SUNDIG$difference) xbar <- mean(SUNDIG$difference) CT <- qt(0.975, 4) # critical t value ST <- sd(SUNDIG$difference) # standard deviation xbar + c(-1, 1) * CT * ST/sqrt(5) [1] 0.6100548 9.3899452 # Second approach t.test(SUNDIG$difference, conf.level = 0.95)$conf [1] 0.6100548 9.3899452 attr(,"conf.level") [1] 0.95 # Third approach t.test(SUNDIG$sun, SUNDIG$digital, paired=TRUE, conf.level = 0.95)$conf [1] 0.6100548 9.3899452 attr(,"conf.level") [1] 0.95 # For full solutions see textbook/lecture slides
